results.headline: Money Is the Fourth Party in a Romantic Triangle

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jerichow

results.summary_short: “Jerichow” proves that, in film as in engineering, the triangle is the strongest and most efficient structural principle.

results.headline: When Love Registers at a Motel, Send Wine

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Management

results.summary_short: “Management” is a sweet-natured comedy that refuses to obey the commercial dictates of Hollywood by allowing its characters to determine their own zany destinies.

results.headline: Love and Salsa

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Big Shot-Caller

results.summary_short: “The Big Shot-Caller,” a minuscule indie variation of “Saturday Night Fever,” moves only in fits and starts.

results.headline: My Brother, My Partner in Crime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Brothers Bloom

results.summary_short: “The Brothers Bloom” is the movie equivalent of an elaborate juggling act whose performers keep dozens of pins wheeling in the air.

results.headline: Holy Mystery! Mayhem at the Vatican

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Angels & Demons

results.summary_short: “Angels & Demons,” without being particularly good, is nonetheless far less hysterical than “The Da Vinci Code.”

results.headline: Moving-Picture Metamorphosis in 3-D

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Anaglyph Tom

results.summary_short: The avant-garde filmmaker Ken Jacobs crafts a digital 3-D fantasia from a scrap of early cinema, complete with red/blue glasses.

results.headline: Tracing Scars From Wounds to a Minority

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Being Jewish in France

results.summary_short: Yves Jeuland’s documentary “Being Jewish in France” is more than three hours long, and its emotional peak comes relatively early.

results.headline: A Story of Hardship and Hope

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Revue

results.summary_short: “Revue” melds disparate images of Soviet life during the 1950s and ’60s into a luminous time capsule of patriotic fervor and political fealty.

results.headline: A Franchise Goes Boldly Backward

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Star Trek

results.summary_short: The latest spinoff from the influential TV show is a testament to television’s power as mythmaker.

results.headline: Blaxploitation Returns

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Next Day Air

results.summary_short: With a script that snaps and characters that pop, “Next Day Air” nears neo-blaxploitation perfection.

results.headline: Unbearable to Watch, Impossible to Evade

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Julia

results.summary_short: “Julia,” starring Tilda Swinton, is a perverse blend of sadism (the director’s, Julia’s) and masochism (ours, Julia’s).

results.headline: A Tapestry of Symbols and Animosities

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Adoration

results.summary_short: “Adoration” is a profound and provocative exploration of cultural inheritance.

results.headline: A Movie Misadventure

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Audience of One

results.summary_short: “Audience of One” follows the descent of a scrappy indie production into a full-blown fiasco and megalomaniacal folly.

results.headline: How the Ball Bounces, on the Field and Off

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Rudo y Cursi

results.summary_short: In “Rudo y Cursi,” two brothers struggle with fame, wealth and the caprices of life in a media-saturated consumer culture.

results.headline: Secret Lives in the Age of Gay Rights

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Outrage

results.summary_short: This indignant and methodical documentary offers a lot of insight into the ideology and psychology of present-day political homophobia.

results.headline: Getting a Handle on Design

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Objectified

results.summary_short: “Objectified” is as sleek and handsome as any of the new and improved household items it exhibits.

results.headline: The Seeds of a Community Conflict

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Garden

results.summary_short: This intricate and compelling documentary paints a saddening portrait of American politics.

results.headline: Fighting Family

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Brothers at War

results.summary_short: “If you can’t join ’em, film ’em” could be the tagline for “Brothers at War,” yet another Iraq war documentary.

results.headline: Madrid Revisited: 3 Paths Meet

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Ashes

results.summary_short: The tangled three-way friendship of Luis Buñuel, Salvador Dalí and Federico García Lorca could make for a fascinating movie. Instead, we have “Little Ashes.”

results.headline: A Patagonian Dream of a Day at the End of a Life

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Window

results.summary_short: Portentous dreams infiltrate the Argentine director Carlos Sorín’s film “The Window.”
